Award.AwardTitle: Focus on Retention in Cohorts of Engineering Students - Plus (FORCES+)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will pursue a promising approach towards recruiting, retaining, and graduating engineering students who transfer from a community college into a four-year degree program. The University of Texas at Arlington (UTA) College of Engineering (COE) will implement a program called: FORCES+ (Focus On Retention in Cohorts of Engineering Students to Provide Lasting University Success). The program will provide scholarships and support activities to incoming freshman and new transfer students in engineering majors. The objectives of FORCES+ are to increase educational opportunities for financially needy, talented undergraduate engineering students; improve retention of freshman and transfer students; and increase participation in internships, cooperative education, research experiences or service opportunities related to their majors.

The project at this Hispanic Serving Institution focuses on building cohorts that of students that enter with comparable levels of readiness to purse an engineering major. Cohorts of incoming students will be formed based on the extent of completion and success in pre-engineering courses such as calculus and physics. The project then utilizes a university-wide required college success course to group transfer students into the same section of the course. This course will then form the foundation for building a cohort for the transfer students. The approach will enable the course to address issues specific to the needs of transfer students. This model is based on an approach that was found to be successful for first year students at this institution. Academic success will also be fostered through support provided for career development and career transitions through optional collaborative research with faculty or industry-based internships with local industry partners.

The FORCES project will carry out formative and summative evaluations of the project through placement exams, surveys, focus groups and exit interviews. These will be used in the context of both baseline data and longitudinal evaluation. Expected improvements in retention of freshman and transfer students in coursework leading up to the engineering professional programs will be measured along with graduation rates and participation in internships, cooperative education, research experiences and/or service opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of FORCES+ project were to (1) increase educational opportunities for financially needy, talented undergraduate engineering students, with emphasis on those from typically underrepresented groups; (2) improve retention of freshman and transfer students in coursework leading up to the engineering Professional Programs and to graduation through a combination of cohort placement and support activities; and (3) increase students’ participation in internships, cooperative education, research experiences and/or service opportunities related to their majors.

The project appears to have achieved its first objective of increasing educational opportunities for underrepresented students; the percentage of underrepresented students in the FORCES+ Cohort 1 was greater than their overall representation within the UTA COE that year and substantially greater for Cohorts 2 and 3 in following years.  

The second objective was evaluated by the project's extermal evaluator. Retention of the FORCES+ cohorts were compared to the retention of similar groups in the COE. The conclusion was that the FORCES+ programs did have a positive impact on student retention compared to COE students with similar backgrounds.  Additionally, the time to the Professional Program and graduation was reduced for the FORCES+ cohorts compared to the similar groups in the COE.

The external evaluator also investigated the entry qualifications and time management characteristics of the retained and not retained FORCES+ freshman and transfer students. The retained and not retained transfer students had very similar transfer hours and transfer GPA but the retained students appeared on average to spend more time working and traveling as well as studying. It would be difficult to draw any conclusions from this result. For the freshman, there were similar results for time management but it appears that the UTA Math Placement test is not a good predictors of retention while SATQ and high school grades were better.

The final comparison made by the evaluator was the demographic make-up of the retained and not retained FORCES+ students. For freshman, three of the demographic populations with lower than 75% retained rates were associated with underrepresented minorities, Females, Hispanic/Latinos, and Black/African Americans. The other freshman demographic group with a lower retention rate was First Generation in College students. For transfer student, the only demographic group with a retained rate less than 75% was Hispanic/Latinos.

The investigators made every effort to increase students’ knowledge of career opportunities such as research and professional internships, i.e., the third objective. This particular objective does not have any direct measures of effectiveness.  The numbers of FORCES+ students that participated in internships was relatively low while they were in the program. However, anecdotal student responses and interactions with peer mentors indicate that students were keenly aware of the importance of internships to career advancement but there were limited
